School of Materials Science and Engineering Northeastern University Shenyang Liaoning 110819 China Graphical abstract This review mainly focuses on the latest research progress, challenges, and development directions of coordination environment regulation in non-precious metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts. The development of highly efficient non-precious metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) electrocatalysts is a key scientific issue for improving the performance of metal-air batteries and fuel cells. Due to the symmetric charge distribution of the traditional M-N4 active site, the adsorption energy of the key oxygen intermediates in the process of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is difficult to reach the optimal value, which seriously limits the catalytic efficiency. The core of solving this problem lies in the accurate modulation of the coordination environment of the M-N4 site, which can realize the breakthrough improvement of the catalytic performance by synergistically optimizing the geometric configuration and electronic structure. In this paper, we systematically analyze the ORR/OER reaction mechanism and then comprehensively review the four main strategies to optimize the coordination environment of M-N-C: metal site regulation, coordination number engineering, non-metal atom doping, and carbon support regulation. Through an in-depth analysis of the structure–activity relationship between the coordination configuration and catalytic performance, the core challenges faced by current research are pointed out, and future research directions are envisioned. This work aims to provide theoretical references for the directional construction of highly efficient M-N-C catalysts with optimized coordination environments. Keywords M-N-C Coordination environment Electronic structure Oxygen reduction reaction Oxygen evolution reaction 1 Introduction The increasing depletion of fossil fuels and the resulting environmental issues have accelerated the transition of the global energy structure to renewable energy sources [1,2]. To achieve efficient storage and utilization of these clean energy sources, innovative energy conversion technologies such as metal-air batteries, fuel cells, and electrolytic water have received extensive attention [3–5]. However, the high energy barriers of key electrocatalytic procedures, such as oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), have become the main bottleneck in the practical application of these clean energy technologies [6–8]. Therefore, the design of effective and durable oxygen electrocatalysts to optimize ORR and OER kinetics has become a core scientific issue to promote the development of clean energy technologies [9–11]. Although precious metal-based catalysts (such as Pt/C, widely used in ORR, and RuO2, commonly used in OER) exhibit excellent catalytic performance, their rarity and high price seriously hinder their extensive commercial application [12–14]. In recent years, non-noble metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) materials have attracted much attention due to their low cost, unique electronic structure, tunable coordination environments, and excellent catalytic performance, which provide new opportunities for the development of clean energy technologies [15–17]. The performance of oxygen electrocatalysts is mainly determined by their adsorption/desorption capacity for ORR and OER intermediates [18,19]. For M-N-C catalysts, the electronic configuration of the metal sites (especially the d-band centers) is highly sensitive to the coordination environment, directly affecting the adsorption/desorption characteristics of oxygen intermediates [20–22]. In other words, the oxygen electrocatalytic activity of M-N-C catalysts is strongly linked to the coordination environment of their metal sites [23,24]. In recent years, the regulation of the coordination environment of M-N-C catalysts has been a promising direction in the field of electrocatalysis [25,26]. By precisely modulating the metal center type [27,28], coordination number [29,30], first or second coordination shell structure [31,32], and carbon carrier [33], the electronic structure of M-N-C catalysts can be effectively optimized to facilitate the adsorption/desorption of reaction intermediates and ultimately significantly enhance their intrinsic catalytic performance. This precise regulation strategy not only provides a new perspective for understanding the catalytic mechanism of M-N-C but also offers a novel avenue for the development of its potential applications [34,35]. At present, the research on the regulation of M-N-C coordination environment has made important breakthroughs, and its application range has also extended from electrocatalysis to frontier fields such as sodium-sulfur batteries [36–44] (Fig. 1 ). Therefore, it is of great scientific significance to systematically summarize the recent research progress on M-N-C coordination environment modulation strategies to promote the further development and application of M-N-C materials. However, the current reviews on the regulation strategies of the M-N-C coordination environment are still relatively few and have certain limitations. In particular, firstly, the existing reviews focus more on monometallic and bimetallic site systems, and the summary of the research progress on trimetallic sites is relatively limited [45–47]. Secondly, the discussion of non-metallic atom doping strategies in the existing reviews mainly focuses on the study of single coordination shells, and the discussion of multi-shell synergy is not sufficient [48–50]. In addition, the influence mechanism of the geometric structure of the carbon carrier on the coordination environment needs to be further clarified [51]. Based on this research status, this paper outlines the basic mechanisms of ORR and OER and then systematically summarizes the recent research progress of the coordination environment regulation strategies of M-N-C catalysts, covering metal site types (monometallic, bimetallic, and trimetallic), coordination number engineering, non-metallic atom doping (single-shell and multi-shell synergy), and carbon carrier regulation (defect engineering and geometric structure design) [52–59] (Fig. 2 ). This paper focuses on the specific influence mechanism of different regulation strategies on ORR and OER performance. Meanwhile, this paper also reveals the structure–activity relationship between the coordination environment and catalytic performance, which provides a theoretical basis for accurately regulating the electronic structure of active sites and the adsorption behavior of reaction intermediates. Finally, this paper also looks forward to the main challenges and future development directions of designing M-N-C catalysts with an ideal coordination environment and high oxygen electrocatalytic activity. 2 ORR and OER mechanisms ORR is a complex procedure with multi-step electron transfer and reaction steps, and therefore, its reaction mechanism has not been fully elucidated [60]. However, according to the existing research, the ORR mechanism in aqueous solution consists of two main types (Fig. 3 a): one is the association mechanism by generating *OOH intermediates in acidic or alkaline electrolytes, and the other is the direct dissociation mechanism of O2 [61]. The choice between these two mechanisms depends mainly on the properties of the electrolyte and the surface structure of the catalyst. In acidic electrolytes, O2 is usually first combined with protons (H+) and electrons (e −) to form *OOH, followed by a series of proton-coupled electron transfer steps, and finally reduced to H2O. In an alkaline electrolyte, O2 may be directly dissociated into two oxygen atoms and then combined with H2O and e − to form OH−. In addition, according to the number of electron transfers, the ORR pathway can be further classified into the four-electron path and the two-electron path [62]. For the direct four-electron path, the specific reactions of ORR in acidic and alkaline electrolytes are shown in Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - → 2 H 2 O (2) O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - → 4 OH - For the indirect two-electron path, the ORR process is more complicated. In acidic electrolytes, the ORR of the two-electron path usually includes the following two steps. (3) O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - → H 2 O 2 (4) H 2 O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - → 2 H 2 O In addition, disproportionation reactions with H2O2 may occur (5) 2 H 2 O 2 → 2 H 2 O + O 2 In alkaline electrolytes, the ORR of the two-electron pathway typically consists of the following two steps. (6) O 2 + H 2 O + 2 e - → HO 2 - + OH - (7) HO 2 - + H 2 O + 2 e - → 3 OH - In addition, disproportionation reaction may also occur (8) 2 HO 2 - → 2 OH - + O 2 The disproportionation reactions (5) and (8) are spontaneous processes without additional electron transfer. Compared with the four-electron pathway, the reaction kinetics of the two-electron pathway are usually slower and prone to produce corrosive intermediates. The appropriate adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates can ensure that the ORR proceeds along the expected four-electron path, thereby improving the selectivity of the catalyst. Therefore, the design and optimization of ORR catalysts require a comprehensive consideration of factors such as the coordination environment, electronic structure, and reaction conditions of the catalyst to regulate the reaction path and improve the catalytic efficiency. OER is the inverse process of ORR, and it is also a complex electrochemical reaction involving multi-step electron transfer. The reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 3(b), and the reaction path varies with the electrolyte [63]. Among them, the four-electron path is the main reaction path of OER [64]. In acidic electrolytes, the specific reaction of OER is as follows (9) 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - In alkaline electrolytes, the specific reaction of OER is as follows (10) 4 OH - → O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - In summary, the reaction mechanism of OER in acidic and alkaline electrolytes usually includes the following steps: Water molecules or OH− are first adsorbed on the active centers on the catalyst surface, and then hydroxyl intermediates (*OH) are generated by electron transfer; *OH further undergoes electron transfer and proton coupling processes to form an oxygen intermediate (*O); finally, the *O intermediate can lead to oxygen evolution in two ways: one is the direct combination of two *O to produce oxygen, and the other is to form the *OOH intermediate first, then generate oxygen molecules and release them into the solution. The formation and transformation process of these intermediates is relatively slow, which seriously limits the reaction rate. Therefore, it is urgent to design efficient catalysts to decrease the reaction activation energy and facilitate the transformation of intermediates to achieve an efficient OER process. 3 Coordination environment regulation strategy The electrocatalytic active centers of M-N-C materials are usually composed of metal sites and their adjacent ligand atoms, forming a typical M-N4 coordination structure [65]. However, the high symmetry of the M-N4 coordination structure limits the electronic configuration regulation of the active metal centers, which in turn affects the adsorption and conversion process of the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction intermediates [66]. According to the Sabatier principle, the adsorption strength of the reaction intermediate on the metal center needs to be moderate. Too strong or too weak is not conducive to obtaining the best catalytic activity [67]. Therefore, by adjusting the symmetry of the M-N4 coordination structure, the electronic configuration of the metal center can be optimized, the adsorption behavior of the reaction intermediate can be adjusted, and the reaction energy barrier can be reduced, thereby improving the catalytic efficiency. Based on this, this paper systematically summarizes the research progress of coordination environment regulation strategies in recent years, mainly including the following four categories: metal site regulation (covering monometallic, bimetallic, and trimetallic site regulation), coordination number engineering, non-metallic atom doping (involving first shell, second shell, and multi-shell coordination), and carbon carrier regulation (such as defect engineering and geometric structure design). Furthermore, this paper presents an in-depth analysis of the intrinsic relationship between the coordination structure and the oxygen electrocatalytic performance and reveals the deeper mechanisms of the coordination environment on the catalytic activity, such as the electron density, d-band centers, spin states, and orbital hybridization between metal and non-metal atoms. 3.1 Metal site regulation 3.1.1 Monometallic site In the M-N-C system, the catalytic activity of the active site is mainly dependent on the electronic structure characteristics of the central metal atom, especially the orbital electron configuration, which has a significant effect on the adsorption energy of the reaction intermediate, thus regulating the overall efficiency of the catalyst [68]. The intrinsic catalytic efficiency of M-N-C can be effectively optimized by reasonably selecting the type of central metal atoms [69]. In recent years, 3d transition metals represented by iron (Fe) [70], cobalt (Co) [71], nickel (Ni) [72], copper (Cu) [73], and manganese (Mn) [74] have been widely used in M-N-C catalysts and exhibit excellent activity in oxygen electrocatalytic reactions. Nevertheless, the exploration and research of novel metal active sites are still in the rapid development stage, which provides a broad space for further improvement of catalytic performance. Tungsten (W), as a 5d transition metal, is in the sixth cycle with platinum (Pt). Its unique electronic structure characteristics enable it to exhibit electrochemical activity similar to Pt. Since the outside shell of W has several valence electrons, its coordination configuration exhibits a remarkable variety, which provides abundant possibilities for the design of catalysts with W as the active site [75]. Recently, Deng et al. [76] successfully constructed atomically dispersed W-N4 sites by ionic liquid-assisted rapid calcination in a vacuum and anchored them on multi-walled carbon nanotubes (S1-W1N4-MWCNTs) (Fig. 4 a). It is found that the W-N4 site has the optimized adsorption energy of the oxygen intermediate and significantly reduced energy barriers of ORR and OER. The experimental results show that S1-W1N4-MWCNTs exhibit a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.916 V in ORR and a potential of 1.644 V (10 mA cm−2) in OER. The difference between the two potentials is only 0.728 V, demonstrating excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. In addition, as a cathode catalyst for low-temperature zinc-air batteries (ZABs), S1-W1N4-MWCNTs not only provide a higher specific capacity but also achieve a charge–discharge cycle life of up to 420 h at −20 °C, and the performance is even better than that at room temperature. This study provides an important reference for the improvement of the bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic activity of tungsten-based catalysts and opens up a new research direction for the construction of efficient and robust non-precious metal catalysts. Rare earth elements, especially lanthanides, tend to form high coordination structures with ligands due to their large atomic radii and multi-shell orbital electron properties [77]. This characteristic helps to increase the interaction between the metal and the carrier, thereby inhibiting the agglomeration of metal centers and improving the electrocatalytic activity and durability [78]. Yin et al. [79] proposed a strategy of synergistic optimization of the active center and the carbon substrate and successfully prepared La-Cl SAs/NHPC catalyst by anchoring the La-N4 center on the surface of nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon (Fig. 4b). The catalyst exhibits excellent ORR performance with E 1/2 up to 0.91 V. The liquid ZAB based on La-Cl SAs/NHPC provides a maximum power density of 260.7 mW cm−2 and a cyclic durability of up to 220 h. The quasi-solid flexible ZAB based on La-Cl SAs/NHPC achieves a peak power density of 68.5 mW cm−2, demonstrating its application prospects in wearable devices. Further density functional theory (DFT) calculations show that the La-N4 center has an optimized electronic structure, which not only accelerates electron transfer but also optimizes the adsorption strength of oxygen intermediates, thus enhancing ORR efficiency. This research offers a novel idea for the design of rare earth-based catalysts. In addition, the lanthanide element gadolinium (Gd) exhibits unique electronic properties due to its electron-rich 4f orbital. Compared with the d orbital, the 4f orbital can provide stronger spin–orbit coupling and a more significant electron delocalization effect [80]. As shown in Fig. 4(c–e), Liu et al. [52] designed a novel Gd-N3 site and successfully prepared a Gd@N/P-HC catalyst with a Gd single atom encapsulated in N/P-doped hollow carbon. The catalyst exhibits excellent ORR performance with E 1/2 of 0.895 V. It was applied to aluminum-air batteries (AABs), achieving a peak power density of 257 mW cm−2 and an energy density of 2916 Wh kg−1, while exhibiting excellent cycle stability. Further DFT calculations and in situ characterization reveal that the Gd-N3 site has an optimized adsorption/desorption kinetics of the oxygen intermediate in the ORR rate-determining step, resulting in a significant enhancement of the catalytic activity. This research opens a novel insight into the application of rare earth elements in oxygen electrocatalysis. In addition to transition metal elements, main group metal elements have gradually become a research hotspot [81]. Main group metal-based catalysts in the s/p-region can form delocalized s/p bands through coordination structure modulation, which can optimize the electron transfer process and significantly enhance the ORR activity [82]. For example, Lin et al. [56] successfully anchored tin (Sn) atoms on rhombohedral porous carbon nanosheets (Sn-N/O-C) by hydrothermal reaction combined with a one-step calcination strategy (Fig. 4f). The catalyst exhibits outstanding ORR performance in alkaline media, with the E 1/2 up to 0.910 V, while demonstrating good long-term durability in acidic and alkaline media. The Sn-N/O-C-based ZAB (Fig. 4g) achieves a superior power density and stable discharge performance. Moreover, the Sn-N/O-C-based proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) exhibits good stability with a current retention of 46% within 20 h. DFT calculations show that the Sn center of Sn-N/O-C has an optimized p-orbital electron configuration (Fig. 4h), which promotes the charge transfer and O2 activation processes, thereby greatly improving the ORR activity. This study promotes the application and development of the main group metals in the p-region for oxygen electrocatalysis and lays an important foundation for future research. Though the efficiency of M-N-C catalysts can be enhanced to a certain extent by regulating the coordination environment and electronic configuration of single metal active centers, their catalytic activity is still limited by the adsorption strength of key oxygen intermediates (such as *OOH and *OH). This is mainly because the single metal active site makes it difficult to meet the optimal adsorption energy demand for each intermediate in the oxygen electrocatalytic reaction involving multiple intermediates. Therefore, future research should focus on the development of bimetallic or multimetallic sites to achieve optimized adsorption energy for reaction intermediates by enriching the types and adsorption modes of active sites, thereby significantly enhancing the overall efficiency of M-N-C catalysts. 3.1.2 Bimetallic site Although single metal site catalysts have demonstrated excellent activity in oxygen electrocatalytic reactions, their performance still has inherent limitations. This limitation stems from the difficulty of simultaneous regulation of multiple reaction intermediates by a single active center; that is, all intermediates must compete for binding sites at the same site, which makes it difficult to simultaneously optimize the adsorption energy of different intermediates [83]. This single-site restriction further hinders the synergy of multi-electron/proton transfer processes, which ultimately restricts the improvement of catalytic efficiency and selectivity. In response to this challenge, researchers have recently turned their attention to bimetallic site catalyst systems [84]. Compared with the traditional single metal site, the bimetallic system exhibits three advantages through the synergistic effect of two neighboring metal sites [85]: (1) increased number of active sites, (2) synergistic regulation of the d-band center, and (3) diversity of adsorption configurations. Specifically, the monometallic site only allows the oxygen intermediate to bind by top-site adsorption, while the bimetallic site can support both top-site and bridge-site adsorption [61]. The diversity of this adsorption mode significantly improves the probability of optimizing the adsorption strength of oxygen intermediates, providing a more flexible regulatory dimension for multi-step oxygen electrocatalytic reactions. Based on the difference in metal components, bimetallic site catalysts can be further divided into two types: homonuclear and heteronuclear [86]. The homonuclear bimetallic site system contains an active center composed of the same metal elements, showing a breakthrough catalytic performance. Through the synergistic adsorption of bimetallic centers, such catalysts are expected to overcome the linear scaling relationship between various oxygen intermediates faced by traditional monometallic sites [87]. As shown in Fig. 5 (a), Zhang et al. [88] synthesized a fully conjugated bisalphen ladder polymer (CoCo-BiSalphen@KB) with a high density of homonuclear cobalt sites in situ on Ketjenblack (KB) substrate by a non-pyrolysis strategy. The strong electron coupling effect between the fully conjugated ladder structure and the carbon support not only promotes the electron transfer between the cobalt site and the oxygen intermediate but also enhances the electron delocalization of the cobalt site, inducing a low-spin to high-spin transformation of the Co 3d electrons (Fig. 5b). In situ characterization (Fig. 5c) and DFT calculations reveal the dynamic evolution of Co2N4O2 active centers and oxygen intermediates, which provides an important basis for understanding the catalytic mechanism. The catalyst has a unique core–shell structure and exhibits excellent ORR performance: the initial potential is 1.10 V, the E 1/2 is 1.00 V, and the performance is not significantly attenuated after 30,000 cycles. In particular, its turnover frequency (TOF) and mass activity are 23 and 75 times higher than those of Pt/C, respectively. The ZAB based on this catalyst achieves excellent power density and durability. This study provides a new spintronic perspective for the precise design of homonuclear bimetallic site catalysts with clear coordination and electronic structures. The heteronuclear bimetallic site system is composed of two different metal elements, and its asymmetric structure exhibits unique properties. Compared with the homonuclear bimetallic site catalyst, the heteronuclear system generates charge redistribution due to the electronegativity difference between metals, which promotes the orbital hybridization between the metal center and the oxygen intermediate [89]. The effective regulation of this electronic structure optimizes the adsorption energy of the oxygen intermediate. In the catalytic process, the heteronuclear bimetallic sites can function through three configurations: isolated bimetallic sites, heteroatom-bridged bimetallic sites, and directly bonded bimetallic sites. This diversity of coordination geometry provides more opportunities to modulate catalytic performance [90]. Isolated bimetallic sites refer to the structure in which two metal atoms are isolated and dispersed on the carrier. This special configuration is derived from the electronic repulsion between metal atoms and the competitive coordination with non-metallic atoms [69]. Isolated bimetallic site catalysts can generate asymmetric charge distribution through the remote interaction between different metals and promote directional charge transfer, thus synergistically reducing the reaction energy barrier and improving the catalytic efficiency. As shown in Fig. 5(d), Peng et al. [91] designed a general synthesis method to successfully fabricate a porous carbon nanosheet supported Fe-Cu double monoatomic catalyst (FeCu-DSAs/NSC) with an asymmetric Fe-N6/Cu-N1S2 coordination structure. DFT calculations show that the synergistic effect of this dispersed bimetallic site and asymmetric heteroatom coordination can effectively regulate the d-band center position of the Fe-Cu 3d orbital to optimize the adsorption/desorption kinetics of oxygen intermediates, thus promoting the bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic process. The experimental results show that FeCu-DSAs/NSC has excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. The rechargeable ZAB based on this catalyst achieves high power density and cycle durability. This study confirms the advantages of heteronuclear bimetallic sites in bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis. Heteroatom-bridged bimetallic sites refer to the unique structures formed by two metal atoms sharing one or two heteroatom ligands [92]. Such a heteroatom-bridged structure has multiple functions: on the one hand, it regulates the charge distribution of the bimetallic site via the electron delocalization effect; on the other hand, it enhances the metal-heteroatom interaction through orbital hybridization, thereby stabilizing the active site [93]. Notably, the heteroatom bridge may not only serve as an active site for the catalytic reaction but also promote the synergy between the bimetallic sites. Compared with isolated bimetallic sites, the heteroatom-bridged structure can shorten the distance between metals, promote d-d orbital hybridization, and effectively regulate the electronic structure of the active center, which optimizes the adsorption behavior of oxygen intermediates and ultimately significantly improves the oxygen electrocatalytic activity. Li et al. [53] developed a precise design strategy for the dual single-atom catalyst (FeCo-SAs) (Fig. 5e). In this study, asymmetric N3-Fe-Co-N4 sites were successfully anchored on nitrogen-doped graphene nanosheets via an innovative two-step synthesis method. Theoretical calculations show that the N3-Fe-Co-N4 configuration has the lowest formation energy (E f), confirming that it is the most thermodynamically stable coordination configuration (Fig. 5f). It is noteworthy that the structural evolution from symmetric Fe-N4 to asymmetric N3-Fe-Co-N4 was achieved through the synergistic effect of the introduction of Co atoms and secondary pyrolysis. In-depth theoretical analysis reveals that this unique coordination structure optimizes the electron spin–orbit of the metal center, promotes charge transport, and significantly increases the density of states near the Fermi level. These properties together optimize the adsorption/desorption behavior of oxygen intermediates, making the catalyst exhibit excellent bifunctional catalytic activity. The electrochemical test results show that the synergistic effect of Fe-Co double atom sites through N atom bridging not only significantly accelerates the kinetic process of ORR and OER, but also greatly improves the stability of the catalyst. The rechargeable ZAB assembled based on FeCo-SAs exhibits excellent overall performance. FeCo-SAs have also been successfully applied to flexible solid-state ZAB, which has great development potential in the field of wearable electronic devices. Moreover, the incorporation of Ni sites can effectively regulate the electronic structure of Fe sites, promote charge transfer, and significantly decrease the energy barrier of the ORR rate-determining step. Zhang et al. [94] innovatively adopted a facile pyrolysis strategy to successfully prepare the FeNi double single atom catalyst (FeNi DSA/N, P-PC) by constructing defect sites in porous carbon support and introducing N, P heteroatoms as metal anchoring sites. Synchrotron radiation X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and DFT calculations confirm that the catalyst has an asymmetric Fe-Ni coordination structure bridged by N atoms, which effectively breaks the symmetry of charge distribution. The strong electronic interaction between Fe and Ni sites and the synergistic regulation of N and P heteroatoms on the active centers jointly promote the significant enhancement of ORR activity. The FeNi DSA/N, P-PC-based ZAB exhibits excellent electrochemical performance. These studies provide new ideas for the design of heteroatom-bridged heteronuclear bimetallic site catalysts. Directly bonded bimetallic sites are structures in which two metal atoms form a unique metal–metal bond [95]. Compared with heteroatom-bridged bimetallic sites, the formation of metal–metal bonds significantly shortens the distance between metal atoms, resulting in stronger d-d orbital coupling. This strong interaction has the following effects: leading to obvious distortion of local coordination symmetry, causing d-band center displacement, and changing the density of electronic states close to the Fermi level. These electronic structure changes can efficiently lower the activation energy barrier of the reaction and facilitate the adsorption/desorption process of oxygen intermediates, thus significantly improving the catalytic efficiency. Theoretical calculations show that the Cu site with a filled d-orbital electron configuration (d10) can serve as an efficient electron donor, which can significantly regulate the electronic configuration of Fe, thereby improving the electrocatalytic activity [96]. Zhang et al. [97] proposed a novel flash nanocomposite strategy and successfully constructed the FeCu-NC catalyst (Fig. 5g). The catalyst achieves a significant enhancement of the trifunctional catalytic activity for ORR, OER, and hydrogen extraction reaction (HER) by uniformly dispersing Fe-Cu heteronuclear bimetallic sites on the N-doped carbon skeleton. DFT calculations reveal the synergistic mechanism of heteronuclear Fe-Cu sites: the intermetallic electron hybridization formed by direct bonding between Fe and Cu sites promotes the d-band center of Fe and Cu to move towards the Fermi level, which not only promotes the charge transfer process but also optimizes the adsorption/desorption behavior of the reaction intermediate at the active site, thus effectively reducing the energy barrier of the electrocatalytic reaction. The experimental results show that FeCu-NC-based ZAB exhibits excellent electrochemical performance, including high open-circuit voltage, significantly improved specific capacity, and excellent cycling performance. Moreover, the catalyst also performs well in electrocatalytic water-splitting applications. This work opens a novel prospect for the construction of multifunctional electrocatalysts with heteronuclear bimetallic active sites. 3.1.3 Trimetallic site The trimetallic active site exhibits a superior synergistic catalytic effect compared to the bimetallic site [98]. In this multi-metal synergistic system, each metal site achieves efficient catalysis through functional division: the main catalytic center is responsible for the key conversion of oxygen intermediates; co-catalytic sites assist the reaction process; the activation site promotes the reactivity of the main catalytic center; and the electronic regulation sites optimize the charge transport process between the main catalytic site and the reaction intermediate by regulating the electronic configuration of the main catalytic site. This multi-level synergy can significantly lower the reaction energy barrier and enhance the activity and stability of the catalyst, providing a creative design concept for the construction of high-efficiency oxygen electrocatalysts. Zhong et al. [99] innovatively developed a heterometallic triatomic catalyst (CoFeCu-TAC), which is precisely anchored on nitrogen-doped graphene support and exhibits excellent bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic performance. The activity and stability of this trimetallic catalytic site are significantly better than traditional monometallic and bimetallic sites. Theoretical calculation (Fig. 6 a–c) reveals the structure–activity relationship of CoFeCu-TAC: The CoN4 site is the main catalytic active center; the introduction of adjacent Fe and Cu atoms breaks the symmetry of the CoN4 site, resulting in the d orbital modulation and downshift of the d-band center, optimizing the binding strength with oxygen intermediates, and effectively decreasing the reaction energy barrier of oxygen electrocatalysis. The CoFeCu-TAC-based rechargeable ZAB (Fig. 6d) exhibits a breakthrough cycle performance. In particular, the CoFeCu-TAC benchmark solid-state ZAB can still operate stably under an extremely low temperature (−60 °C), demonstrating excellent environmental adaptability. This study confirms the superiority of the three-metal site design strategy, which promotes the development of multi-atom synergistic catalysis in the field of energy conversion. Zn has a unique dual function in the catalytic system. On the one hand, as an electron regulator, Zn can efficiently modulate the electronic configuration of the active center and significantly enhance the reaction kinetics. On the other hand, with its prominent spatial confinement effect, Zn can promote the uniform dispersion of other M-N4 sites and effectively inhibit their aggregation [100]. This electron-space synergistic regulation mechanism not only optimizes the intrinsic activity of the catalytic active site but also guarantees the structural stability of the catalytic material, which offers a new insight into the design of efficient and stable trimetallic site catalysts. Chen et al. [54] synthesized an asymmetric coordination heterotrimetallic catalyst (ZnCoFe-TAC/SNC) by the wet chemical method. Its structural characteristics are that nitrogen-coordinated Co and Zn atoms and sulfur and nitrogen double-coordinated Fe atoms (ZnN3CoN3FeN2S) form atomically dispersed active sites on sulfur/nitrogen co-doped carbon substrates (Fig. 6e). The outstanding activity of the catalyst is due to the synergistic effect of metal-nonmetal bonds (ZnN, CoN, FeN, FeS) and the electronic coupling effect among metals, thereby optimizing the electronic configuration of the heterotrimetallic active site. The experimental results show that ZnCoFe-TAC/SNC exhibits superior bifunctional performance, and the ZAB based on this catalyst achieves a remarkable peak power density of 304 mW cm−2. Based on in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) analysis, the Co atom is identified as the major catalytic active site, while the Fe site plays a co-catalytic role, and the Zn atom optimizes the local electronic environment of the active site through electronic regulation. Further DFT calculations show that the electronic synergistic effect among Zn, Co, and Fe can effectively adjust the adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates and significantly improve the reaction kinetics. This study provides a novel insight into the design of effective asymmetric multi-metal site catalysts and promotes the development of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. The introduction of lanthanide elements has brought new regulatory dimensions to the three-metal site system. Taking cerium (Ce) as an example, its special electronic structure characteristics are mainly manifested in the unfilled 4f orbital, which endows it with variable electronic configurations and flexible coordination numbers, allowing it to form diverse coordination environments [101]. These characteristics enable Ce to have a stronger synergistic effect with other metals, especially in promoting the activation of the main catalytic center, which opens a novel direction for the construction of efficient oxygen electrocatalysts. Zheng et al. [102] successfully constructed a novel FeZnCe trimetallic site catalyst (FeZnCe5-NC) by the wet chemical method. The material is co-anchored on the nitrogen/oxygen co-doped carbon support by nitrogen-coordinated Fe/Zn single atoms (FeN4/ZnN4) and oxygen-coordinated Ce nanoclusters (Ce-O-Ce). X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) reveals this unique Fe-Zn-Ce ternary coordination configuration. In particular, the introduction of Ce promotes the activation of Fe sites. With the advantage of the electronic synergy among the three metal components, the catalyst exhibits excellent ORR performance. The FeZnCe5-NC-based ZAB achieves outstanding discharge performance and durability. This work promotes the development of highly dispersed multi-component M-N-C catalysts, which is of great significance for advancing oxygen electrocatalysis. Although bi/tri-metal-site catalysts have shown great potential in breaking through the limitation of single-metal-site catalytic performance, there are still many challenges for their further development: the difference in physicochemical properties of multi-metals makes the controllable synthesis of highly dispersed and stable multimetallic sites (such as four/five metal systems) extremely difficult; the fine structure analysis (including coordination configuration, atomic spacing, etc.) and synergistic mechanism elucidation (such as active center confirmation, spin state regulation, etc.) of multimetallic sites require the establishment of more sophisticated characterization-computation coupling technologies; the construction of efficient machine learning prediction models will become a key means to accelerate the optimization of multi-metal component matching and achieve a breakthrough in catalytic performance. The resolution of these challenges will advance the evolution of multi-metal site catalysts toward higher activity and better stability. 3.2 Coordination number engineering Coordination number engineering optimizes the adsorption behavior of oxygen intermediates and enhances catalytic efficiency by precisely modulating the coordination number of metal sites to construct unsaturated (M-N x , x less than 4) or supersaturated (M-N x , x greater than 4) coordination structures that break the planar electron symmetry distribution of conventional M-N4 sites [103]. The unsaturated coordinated M-N x sites can increase the electron density of the metal site and facilitate the adsorption and desorption of oxygen intermediates while lowering the reaction energy barrier and accelerating the electron transfer, which significantly improves the overall catalytic efficiency and reaction kinetics. Tang et al. [104] successfully realized the precise tuning of the first coordination shell of the Co-N-C catalyst by using the bidentate ligand-assisted pyrolysis method. The asymmetric low-coordinated Co-N3 active sites were constructed in the atomically dispersed Co-N3-C/CNT catalyst prepared by this strategy, which significantly improved the intrinsic catalytic activity of ORR. The theoretical calculation results (Fig. 7 a, b) reveal that the asymmetric Co-N3 structure breaks the symmetrical charge arrangement of the traditional Co-N4 structure and induces the electron enrichment effect in the Co center, which not only facilitates the activation process of oxygen molecules but also optimizes the adsorption and desorption behavior of key oxygen intermediates, thus significantly improving the ORR kinetics. Based on this advantage, Co-N3-C/CNT-based ZAB demonstrates an excellent specific capacity. This study not only establishes a universal method for the construction of low-coordination M-N3 active centers but also highlights the important value of low-coordination engineering strategies in the design of high-efficiency M-N-C electrocatalysts. In addition, Li et al. [105] innovatively applied the etching-anchoring approach to successfully prepare the Fe-N to successfully prepare the Fe-NC-Cor catalyst with a low-coordinated Fe-N3 active center. Different from the traditional Fe-N4 structure, this special low coordination configuration effectively perturbs the electronic symmetry arrangement of the metal site and optimizes the adsorption strength of the Fe atom to the oxygen intermediate. The advanced in situ characterization technology reveals the dynamic evolution characteristics of the Fe-N3 coordination environment in the ORR procedure: the stretching vibration of the FeN bond and the electron density rearrangement significantly contribute to the dissociation of *OOH and the protonation of *O, thus achieving an efficient four-electron transfer path. This catalyst exhibits excellent ORR performance, including a high E 1/2 of 0.89 V and a four-electron selectivity of 99.1%. Fe-NC-Cor-based ZAB also exhibits excellent peak power density. This study not only elucidates the dynamic evolution mechanism of the low coordination configuration in the catalytic process but also delivers insights into the construction of efficient M-N-C catalysts. The supersaturated coordination M-N x sites (such as M-N5) exhibit distinct electronic properties from the unsaturated structure: they form a high coordination structure by introducing an axial N ligand, which not only reduces the electron density of the metal site and promotes the metal to present a higher valence state but also induces an asymmetric electron distribution and significantly modulates the d-band center position. This unique coordination environment, on the one hand, optimizes the adsorption energy of the oxygen intermediate and significantly enhances the catalytic efficiency; on the other hand, it inhibits the migration and agglomeration of metal centers by enhancing the interaction between metal and support, thus dramatically improving the stability of the catalyst and providing a new way to design oxygen electrocatalysts with high activity and long life. Luo et al. [106] accurately constructed a bifunctional oxygen electrocatalyst (CoN5/PCNF) with axial nitrogen coordination while maintaining the structural integrity of carbon nanofibers by using innovative surface atom adsorption-flashing heating technology. Theoretical calculations show that the axial nitrogen coordination induces the charge rearrangement of the Co center and optimizes the d-band center, which significantly promotes the adsorption and desorption of oxygen intermediates and reduces the ORR/OER energy barrier. In situ characterization confirms that the CoN5 site dominates the catalytic process, and the catalyst exhibits excellent bifunctional activity (OER overpotential of 270 mV@10 mA cm−2 and ORR half-wave potential of 0.92 V). In particular, the assembled flexible ZAB based on it possesses a cycle stability of 36 h, showing good wearable application potential. In addition, the axial N-coordination can efficiently regulate the electronic configuration characteristics of the Fe active site: by precisely adjusting the d-orbital electron distribution, changing the d-band center position, and enhancing the spin polarization effect, the intrinsic catalytic performance of the Fe site is significantly enhanced. Chen et al. [107] explored the axial coordination strategy to successfully construct an atomically dispersed Fe-N5 site anchored on multi-channel N-doped carbon nanofibers (FeN5@NMCNFs) (Fig. 7c). The theoretical calculations (Fig. 7d–g) show that the incorporation of axial nitrogen ligands efficiently breaks the symmetry of the FeN4 plane and induces a significant spin polarization effect. This is manifested by the downward shift of the d-band center of the Fe sites and the reduction of the spin crossover energy gap, as well as the combination of ferromagnetic/antiferromagnetic transition characteristics. This unique electronic structure optimizes the adsorption behavior of the oxygen intermediate and lowers the reaction energy barrier. The prepared FeN5@NMCNFs catalyst exhibits excellent ORR activity and stability, and both liquid and all-solid ZABs assembled based on this material exhibit excellent electrochemical performance. This work opens a novel prospect for optimizing the performance of M-N-C catalysts by modulating the spin states through high coordination engineering. Although coordination number engineering has proven to be effective in regulating the electronic structure and catalytic activity of the monometallic site, its research scope still needs to be further expanded. Future research should focus on the precise regulation of the coordination number of bimetallic and multimetallic site systems, which can realize stronger electronic coupling and synergistic effects among metal sites by constructing more complex asymmetric coordination structures. The synergistic coordination regulation of multimetallic sites is expected to break through the performance limit of existing single-metal sites, which will open up a novel way for the development of new-generation efficient electrocatalysts and also help to deeply understand the essential mechanism of multi-metal center synergistic catalysis. 3.3 Non-metallic atom doping 3.3.1 The first shell coordination The accurate modulation of the coordination environment and electronic configuration of the M-N4 active site can be achieved by introducing non-metallic heteroatoms (X = B, N, O, F, P, S, Cl, etc.) with different electronegativity and atomic radius [108]. This heteroatom doping strategy works mainly through two mechanisms [109]: first, the first coordination shell modulation, where the heteroatom directly coordinates with the metal center to form a new active site; second, the second coordination shell modulation, where the heteroatom modifies the carbon skeleton around the metal center, indirectly affecting the electronic structure of the metal site via the long-range electron delocalization effect. Both modulations can effectively optimize the adsorption behavior of the oxygen intermediates and thus significantly improve the catalytic performance. Novel active centers with asymmetric electron distributions can be constructed by precise modulation of the first coordination shell of the M-N4 site by non-metallic atoms. This coordination engineering can induce specific charge/spin rearrangements near the Fermi energy level to form catalytic sites with tunable electron densities, thus realizing the balanced regulation of the adsorption–desorption process of oxygen intermediates. It is particularly noteworthy that the partial substitution of planar coordination N atoms by non-metallic elements can not only effectively stabilize the metal center and inhibit its agglomeration tendency through the formation of MX chemical bonds but also finely regulate the position of the metal d-band center and optimize its orbital interactions with the oxygen intermediates, which ultimately achieves a synergistic enhancement of the catalytic activity and stability [51]. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), Guan et al. [110] successfully constructed a highly efficient Co1-BNG catalyst by pyrolysis strategy. In the catalyst structure, the asymmetric coordinated cobalt active center (Co-N3B) is anchored on the nitrogen and boron co-doped graphene substrate, showing significant ORR activity and stability. DFT calculations and in situ characterization reveal that the introduction of low electronegativity B atoms promotes the upward shift of the d-band center of Co, thereby enhancing the hybridization between the Co 3d orbital and the O 2p orbital close to the Fermi level and ultimately significantly improving the adsorption capacity of the Co center for oxygen intermediates. Based on this, Co1-BNG-based ZAB exhibits excellent electrochemical performance. Compared with B, S has a larger atomic radius, which allows for greater asymmetry in the local coordination structure of the active metal center, resulting in more significant electronic structure regulation and greater improvement in catalytic activity. For example, the incorporation of S atoms into the first coordination shell of the Fe site can create the Fe-N-C catalyst with a highly asymmetric coordination environment to improve its catalytic efficiency for ORR and OER. Ting et al. [111] successfully constructed a highly asymmetric N, S co-coordinated Fe-N3S1 site and anchored it on a carbon black (CB) support deposited by flame roasting to form the Fe-N3S1/CB catalyst. The catalyst exhibits excellent bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic performance. DFT calculations show that this asymmetric Fe-N3S1 coordination configuration facilitates the desorption of *OH in ORR and accelerates the desorption of O2 in OER, thereby improving the catalytic efficiency. The Fe-N3S1/CB-based ZAB reaches a peak power density of 365.7 mW cm−2 and exhibits a cycle stability of up to 333.3 h. In addition, the introduction of S atoms into the first coordination shell of the Co active center can also effectively improve the ORR activity and stability of the Co-N-C catalyst in an acidic environment. Chen et al. [65] designed a CoN3S-PC catalyst, in which the Co center is coordinated with N and S atoms on the porous carbon substrate. DFT shows that the S atom as an electron donor destroys the charge symmetry of the Co active center and enhances the interaction with the Co 3d orbital. This modification enhances the activation of O2 and the adsorption of oxygen intermediates, thus significantly improving the ORR activity and four-electron selectivity. Therefore, the PEMFC assembled based on CoN3S-PC exhibits excellent performance and durability, with a peak power density of 1.32 W cm−2 in an oxygen environment. The P atom also has a large atomic radius, and the d-band center position can be customized by adjusting the coordination environment of the metal atom, thereby optimizing the catalytic activity. Yu et al. [112] successfully synthesized Ni-N, P/CNFs catalysts by constructing Ni-N3-P active sites on porous carbon nanofibers. Theoretical calculations show that the d-band center of the Ni atom coordinated with three N atoms and one P atom has a moderate position, which makes the Ni center have a suitable adsorption and desorption behavior for the H/O intermediate, which is beneficial to the HER and OER kinetics. As a result, Ni-N, P/CNFs exhibit extraordinary HER, OER, and water splitting performance. Acidic HER requires only an ultra-low overpotential of 38 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Non-metallic heteroatom dopants can not only occupy the planar coordination sites of the M-N4 active center but also modulate the electronic configuration of the metal sites through axial coordination. Crystal field theory suggests that the difference in axial ligand field strength significantly alters the energy level splitting of the central metal d orbital, thereby regulating its spin state distribution [113]. This will help to synergistically regulate ORR and OER catalytic activity by optimizing the adsorption behavior of oxygen intermediates. Qiao et al. [55] successfully constructed two axial ligand-differentiated Fe-N4 catalysts (Cl-FeN4 and N-FeN4) by accurately controlling the chloride chemical potential in FeCl3 and FeCl2 vapor environments, using the pyridine nitrogen enrichment characteristics of the covalent triazine skeleton, based on the competitive coordination of Cl and pyridine N to the Fe-N4 axial sites. As shown in Fig. 8(b), the precise regulation of the Fe central spin state from the high spin (HS) to the intermediate spin (MS) is realized by switching the axial ligand from the weak field Cl to the strong field pyridine N. This results in the excellent bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic performance of N-FeN4 (ΔE = 0.68 V). Theoretical calculations reveal that the spin state transition significantly reduces the OER overpotential while maintaining excellent ORR performance by adjusting the *OH adsorption energy. The N-FeN4-based ZAB exhibits long cycle stability of more than 1000 h. This research presents a paradigm for optimizing the bifunctional catalytic performance by regulating the spin state through axial ligand engineering. Halogen ligands with significantly higher electronegativity than nitrogen (such as F, Cl, etc.) can also achieve axial coordination. Such strong electronegative ligands effectively reduce the electron cloud density of the metal site through a greater axial electron traction effect, thereby accurately regulating the adsorption strength of oxygen intermediates and ultimately significantly improving the overall efficiency of the catalytic system. Cao et al. [114] successfully introduced axial F atoms into the planar structure of CoN4 through a hydrothermal-chemical vapor deposition synergistic strategy and constructed a Co-FNC catalyst with a square-pyramid CoN4-F1 coordination configuration. As shown in Fig. 8(c), CoN4-F1 exhibits the lowest formation energy, confirming the thermodynamic spontaneity of the transition from six-coordinated Co-F6 to five-coordinated square conical CoN4-F1. In situ spectroscopic analysis shows that the coordination structure not only significantly enhances the adsorption capacity of *OOH intermediates but also promotes the dissociation of *OOH into *O and *OH by promoting the cleavage of the OO bond, effectively guiding the four-electron transfer path. Theoretical calculations further confirm that axial F coordination significantly accelerates ORR kinetics by reducing the electron density of the Co site and optimizing the *OH desorption energy barrier. The prepared Co-FNC catalyst exhibits excellent ORR activity and ZAB performance while maintaining outstanding stability. This study provides important guidance for the design of efficient axially coordinated metal catalytic centers. In addition, the introduction of axial F atoms can improve the catalytic activity of the Fe-N4 site while enhancing its structural stability, effectively inhibiting the dissolution of its metal center in an acidic environment. Bai et al. [115] regulated the coordination environment and macroscopic hydrophobic properties of Fe-N-C catalysts by doping F atoms, which balanced the activity and stability of fuel cells. Specifically, the highly electronegative F atom reduces the electron density of the Fe center, enhancing the ORR kinetics. In addition, the strong coupling between the Fe center and the F atom significantly increases the dissolution energy of Fe, thereby improving the durability of the F-Fe-N-C catalyst. Equally important, the unique hydrophobicity of F atoms can effectively remove excess water in PEMFC, significantly reducing oxygen transport resistance, and thus improving its performance. Therefore, the F-Fe-N-C-based PEMFC exhibits a high peak power density of 1.1 W cm−2 and can retain 90% of the power density after 30,000 cycles of accelerated stress testing, which has great application potential. Notably, the axial Cl ligand exhibits a unique dual function: it can not only optimize the electronic configuration of the catalytic site but also efficiently inhibit the competitive adsorption of Cl− on the active site in the seawater electrolyte, which significantly improves the practical efficiency and service life of ZAB based on seawater electrolyte. Liu et al. [116] innovatively introduced a highly electronegative Cl ligand into the axial direction of the Fe single atom site (Cl-FeSA/NC) to realize the Cl− adsorption inhibition and active center protection through the construction of a local negative electric interface. DFT calculations show that the charge rearrangement between the axial Cl− and Fe sites simultaneously achieves two important effects: (1) optimization of the electronic structure of the Fe site and the adsorption energy of the oxygen intermediate and (2) formation of a negative electric shielding layer around the active center, which effectively blocks the corrosion and poisoning of Fe sites by seawater Cl−. As shown in Fig. 8(d), in situ Raman spectroscopy confirms that the axial Cl− coordination in Cl-FeSA/NC not only promotes the formation of the oxygen intermediate but also accelerates its protonation kinetic process. The catalyst exhibits superior ORR performance and durability in seawater systems, and the assembled ZAB achieves a significant peak power density. This research establishes a new paradigm for the axial coordination design of ORR catalysts for seawater electrolytes. In addition to halogen ligands, oxygen-containing element ligands (such as O, S, hydroxyl, and SO2) can also be used as axial ligands to modify the M-N4 active center. Qu et al. [117] proposed a breakthrough axial coordination regulation strategy to optimize ORR activity and reaction kinetics by accurately regulating the Lewis acidity of Fe sites. In this study, DFT calculations reveal that the Lewis acidity of the Fe site directly determines the adsorption behavior of the key ORR intermediate (*OH), which in turn dominates the ORR performance. As shown in Fig. 8(e), based on this theoretical prediction, the research team innovatively introduced various sulfur species (Lewis bases) at the Fe-N4 site for planar or axial coordination and successfully realized the precise regulation of Lewis acidity. Among them, the –SO2 axially coordinated Fe1-N4SO2 configuration exhibits optimal Lewis acidity, and the best theoretical activity is obtained by balancing the adsorption strength of ORR intermediates. As shown in Fig. 8(f), the Fe1-N4SO2/NC catalyst successfully synthesized by the molecular cage encapsulation strategy exhibits ORR performance beyond the benchmark in both alkaline and acidic media. The assembled solid-state ZAB exhibits superior environmental adaptability, maintaining high power/energy density and outstanding stability over a wide temperature range. The axial coordination regulation paradigm based on Lewis acidity established in this study represents a universal approach to extending the rational development of M-N-C catalysts. In addition to the planar/axial coordination regulation of a single non-metallic heteroatom, the multi-dimensional regulation of the first coordination shell of the M-N4 active center can be achieved through the synergistic coordination of different heteroatoms in planar and axial positions. As shown in Fig. 8(g), Tan et al. [118] developed a salt effect-induced synthesis strategy and successfully constructed atomically dispersed Fe sites with N/P plane coordination and Cl axial coordination. These active centers were then anchored in a three-dimensional porous carbon network (Fe-NP-Cl-C). Theoretical calculations confirm that the salt effect can simultaneously promote the formation of FeP bonds and FeCl bonds. The constructed Fe-N2P2-Cl sites efficiently lower the energy barrier of the ORR procedure and accelerate the reaction kinetics by optimizing the spatial distribution of charges. The catalyst demonstrates superior ORR catalytic performance and outstanding stability. This work not only elucidates the synergistic effect of various heteroatoms in modulating the first coordination shell structure of the metal center but also provides an important reference for the design of efficient M-N-C oxygen electrocatalysts. P atoms can not only participate in the planar coordination but also produce a synergistic effect with the planar coordinated S atom through the axial coordination mode to achieve precise regulation of the first coordination shell of the metal center, thereby optimizing its electronic structure. Lv et al. [119] developed a facile synergistic regulation strategy and successfully prepared a hollow porous Co-NSP-HPC catalyst with N, S plane coordination and P axial coordination, which constructed an asymmetric highly coordinated CoN3SP structure. Theoretical calculations confirm that the synergistic coordination of S and P effectively regulates the electronic configuration of the Co active center, which is manifested by facilitating the d-p orbital hybridization between Co and O atoms and inducing the negative displacement of the d-band center. These electronic structural changes facilitate the adsorption behavior of oxygen intermediates, making the Co-NSP-HPC catalyst exhibit excellent bifunctional electrocatalytic activity, and the ZAB assembled based on the catalyst also exhibits excellent electrochemical performance. This study provides an important theoretical basis and practical scheme for regulating the electronic structure of metal centers by constructing asymmetric high coordination configurations. With its high electronegativity, the hydroxyl group can be used as an axial ligand to form an asymmetric coordination structure with the metal center coordinated by the planar S, which enhances the catalytic performance by dual modulation of the charge distribution in the active site. Yuan et al. [120] constructed a five-coordinated FeN3SOH active site on the N, S-codoped porous hollow leaf-like carbon carrier (FeSA/N, S-PHLC) by using a host–guest sulfidation-assisted strategy (Fig. 8h). Theoretical calculations reveal that the asymmetric structure formed by planar N, S coordination, axial OH coordination, and the abundant pyridine nitrogen synergy jointly optimize the 3d electron orbital arrangement of the Fe active center, thereby improving the adsorption and desorption behavior of the oxygen intermediate. The catalyst exhibits outstanding ORR activity in acidic and alkaline media. This study confirms the unique advantage of accurately regulating the first shell of the metal center through the electronegativity-differentiated heteroatom coordination strategy. Expanding the monometallic site system, the first shell coordination regulation strategy can be further applied to the design of bimetallic site catalysts, which can synergistically improve the intrinsic catalytic efficiency through the precise modulation of the atomic distribution and electronic configuration. Wang et al. [121] successfully constructed an atomically dispersed boron-coordinated bimetallic catalyst (FeN4B-NiN4B). The innovation lies in the introduction of boron atoms into the first coordination shell of the FeN4-NiN4, forming the Fe-B-N/Ni-B-N bridge structure to achieve geometric-electronic structure dual regulation. Compared with the undoped FeN4-NiN4, the catalyst exhibits excellent ORR/OER bifunctional activity. Theoretical calculations reveal that the central structure distortion of FeN4B and NiN4B induced by boron doping has a dual effect: (1) triggering asymmetric charge distribution and (2) facilitating charge transfer between metal and boron. This synergistic effect optimizes the adsorption–desorption equilibrium of oxygen intermediates, leading to a significant reduction of the ORR/OER energy barrier. The experimental results show that the FeN4B-NiN4B-based ZAB achieves a peak power density of 236.9 mW cm−2 and maintains an ultra-long cycle stability of 1100 h. This study provides a new paradigm for the modulation of the first coordination shell of bimetallic site catalysts, which is an important guide for the rational design of bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. 3.3.2 The second shell coordination The non-metallic heteroatoms can still achieve significant modulation by entering the second coordination shell without directly participating in the coordination of the metal center. Their long-range electron delocalization effect can indirectly reconstruct the electronic configuration of the active site, thus optimizing the adsorption and desorption equilibrium of the oxygen intermediate and ultimately improving the oxygen electrocatalytic performance. Notably, this indirect modulation can produce a modification effect superior to that of the first coordination shell. Zhang et al. [122] constructed the FeSN-C and FeN-SC catalyst systems with the S atom in the first and second coordination shells, respectively, and elucidated this phenomenon through comparative studies (Fig. 9 a, b). Experiments show that FeN-SC exhibits superior ORR performance (E 1/2 = 0.92 V). Theoretical analysis (Fig. 9c, d) reveals that FeN-SC not only has a greater electron density of states close to the Fermi level but also exhibits the lowest ORR rate-determining step energy barrier. In comparison with the direct coordination of the first shell, the S atom of the second coordination shell more efficiently regulates the electronic structure and charge transfer process of the Fe center, which significantly optimizes the adsorption and desorption behavior of the oxygen intermediate, thus accelerating the ORR kinetics. This study systematically analyzes the regulation mechanism of non-metallic heteroatoms in various coordination shells and especially demonstrates the key role of the second coordination shell regulation in the design of catalytic materials. As an efficient medium for charge regulation, the sulfur atom has a dual regulation function: the charge arrangement of the metal site can be reconstructed by regulating the electronic properties of the active site (electron-withdrawing/electron-donating effect) to optimize its adsorption strength for the oxygen intermediate. It can also enhance the intrinsic catalytic performance by modifying the MN bond characteristics (Fig. 10 ). Zhu et al. [123] designed a simple approach to successfully synthesize the FeZ-N/S0.6-C catalyst with FeN4C x S y sites (Fig. 9e). The doping of sulfur atoms in the second coordination shell significantly prolongs the bond length of Fe-N due to their large atomic radii and moderate electronegativity. This structural change allows the catalyst to achieve excellent ORR performance (E 1/2 = 0.93 V). The solid-state ZAB assembled based on this catalyst exhibits excellent performance, showing good prospects for practical applications. This research establishes the structure–activity relationship between sulfur doping in the second coordination shell and catalytic performance, providing a novel paradigm for the design of industrial-grade non-noble metal catalysts. The phosphorus atom with moderate electronegativity can effectively regulate the second coordination shell at the M-N4 site through a dual mechanism: destroying the original symmetrical geometric/charge distribution and changing the interaction characteristics of metal-nitrogen coordination bonds. Qi et al. [124] employed the experimental design strategy guided by theoretical calculations (Fig. 9f) to accurately modulate the coordination number and spatial configuration of P atoms in the second coordination shell of the CoN4 site. The hierarchical porous carbon-supported Co-N/P-C catalyst was successfully prepared. The combination of EXAFS and DFT analyses confirms that the P atom is stably present in the second coordination shell of the Co center. This coordination mode significantly improves the ORR kinetic performance by reconstructing the valence electron orbital of Co 3d, weakening the Co-N interaction, and optimizing the adsorption energy of the *OOH intermediate. The catalyst exhibits excellent ORR performance and stability, and the assembled ZAB based on it has both high specific capacity and power density, showing good industrial application potential. This study not only elucidates the electronic regulation mechanism of the P coordination of the second shell on the active center but also provides a universal approach for the rational design of M-N-C catalysts. The introduction of phosphorus atoms can not only regulate the interaction characteristics of metal-nitrogen coordination bonds but also effectively inhibit the loss of nitrogen by bonding with nitrogen atoms to form PN bonds, which promotes the formation of more M-N4 active sites and enhances their structural stability. Qin et al. [125] realized the ultrafast construction of phosphorus-doped FeN4 sites on carbon nanotube substrates (P-FeN4@CNTs) by flash Joule heating (FJH) technology. DFT calculations (Fig. 9g) reveal that the incorporation of P atoms has a dual effect: firstly, it significantly inhibits the escape of nitrogen during the high-temperature transient process, thereby increasing the number of FeN4 sites; secondly, it breaks the planar symmetry of the FeN4 structure, inducing non-uniform charge distribution and lowering the energy barriers of the rate-determining step, which ultimately optimizes the ORR performance. Benefiting from the above advantages, the catalyst exhibits superior ORR catalytic efficiency. This study further confirms that FJH technology can be extended to the efficient synthesis of M-N-C catalysts and the precise regulation of heteroatoms. 3.3.3 Multi-shell coordination In summary, the regulation mechanism of non-metallic heteroatoms on the coordination environment of M-N4 active centers mainly includes two ways: firstly, heteroatoms directly replace part of the nitrogen atoms in the first coordination shell of M-N4 to establish coordination bonds with the metal center and construct an asymmetric local coordination structure, which destroys the symmetry of the electron distribution; secondly, heteroatoms are embedded in the second coordination shell of M-N4 to indirectly optimize the electronic structure of the metal site by adjusting the electron donor/acceptor characteristics of the carbon carrier. Therefore, the concurrent introduction of non-metallic heteroatoms into different coordination shells of the M-N4 active site can synergistically regulate its coordination configuration and electronic structure, thereby significantly improving the catalytic activity. In addition, this synergistic regulation strategy can also enhance the interaction between the metal center and the carbon support, efficiently inhibit the migration and agglomeration of the metal center, and realize the improvement of catalyst stability [126]. As shown in Fig. 11 (a), Chi et al. [127] predicted by theoretical calculations that a nove Fe-N3S1-S active site can be constructed when S atoms are simultaneously embedded in the first coordination shell (forming the Fe-N3S1 configuration) and the second coordination shell (forming the C-S-C thiophene structure) of the Fe-N4 active center. The incorporation of S atoms can redistribute the charge density of the Fe-N4 site and move down the d-band center of Fe, thereby weakening the adsorption strength of the oxygen-containing intermediate. Compared to the modulation strategy of the single coordination shell, this double-shell doping significantly enhances the catalytic efficiency of ORR. According to this theoretical prediction, the research team prepared a nitrogen and sulfur co-doped graphene-based catalyst (Fe-SAc/NSG, Fig. 11b, c) with Fe-N3S1 active sites by salt template polymerization-pyrolysis. The catalyst exhibits excellent ORR performance, and the assembled ZAB based on it has both high power output and long-term stability. This research presents a novel idea for the construction of high-performance M-N-C catalysts through a multi-coordinated shell synergistic doping strategy. Non-metallic heteroatoms can not only synergistically regulate the multi-coordinated shell structure of single metal sites but also extend to the coordination environment regulation of bimetallic site systems. By precisely designing the heteroatom doping of different coordination shells, the symmetrical charge distribution of bimetallic sites can be effectively broken, and the optimal adsorption equilibrium of various reaction intermediates can be achieved, thereby improving the comprehensive performance of the catalytic system. Zhang et al. [57] innovatively developed a sulfur and nitrogen co-doped carbon matrix (SNC) with a defect-rich structure and used its defect sites to anchor a diatomic iron active center with asymmetric nitrogen and sulfur coordination (A-Fe2S1N5/SNC, Fig. 11d). Theoretical calculations reveal that the outstanding activity of the catalyst is attributed to the self-generated polarization effect induced by its unique asymmetric double iron site configuration (N2S1Fe-FeN3), which realizes the optimal balance of the adsorption/desorption energy barrier of the oxygen intermediates and a significant reduction of the reaction activation energy. In particular, the synergistic coordination of S atoms in different coordination shells also greatly improves the structural stability of the catalytic materials. Thanks to these advantages, the catalyst exhibits exceptional OER activity and ultra-long stability. The alkaline anion exchange membrane electrolyzer based on this catalyst (Fig. 11e) exhibits excellent durability, fully demonstrating its practical application value. The heteroatom double-shell modulation strategy proposed in this study can also be further extended to bimetallic site catalyst systems such as Co, Ni, Cu, and Mn, which provides a new idea for balancing catalytic activity and stability. The coordination regulation strategy of non-metallic heteroatoms is not only limited to the modification of multi-coordinated shells by the same heteroatom but also can be extended to the synergistic regulation of multiple heteroatoms with different atomic radii and electronegativity. This multiple heteroatom synergistic strategy can more effectively induce the asymmetric distribution of charge at the active center and realize the fine optimization of the coordination microenvironment and electronic configuration. More importantly, the synergistic effect of different heteroatoms can construct richer types and numbers of active sites, providing diverse adsorption modes for multiple intermediates in the ORR and OER processes, thereby systematically optimizing the adsorption energy and significantly improving the catalytic activity [128]. Liu et al. [129] modulated the Fe-N4 sites by axial S coordination (the first coordination shell) and neighboring P atom modification (the second coordination shell) and successfully constructed a new coordination structure of Fe-N4SP (Fig. 11f). DFT calculations show that this double heteroatom synergistic modification strategy effectively breaks the electronic symmetry of the Fe-N4 center, which not only lowers the d-band center position of Fe but also enhances the spin polarization effect. The precise regulation of this electronic structure significantly promotes the activation and reduction process of oxygen molecules and optimizes the adsorption energy of oxygen intermediates, enabling the Fe-N4SP site to exhibit excellent intrinsic ORR activity. Experimentally, the research team successfully prepared the Fe-N4SP/NPS-HC catalyst with Fe-N4SP active sites in N, P, and S co-doped hollow carbon nanocages. The catalyst demonstrates exceptional ORR efficiency in both acidic and alkaline media. The ZAB assembled based on this catalyst exhibits a high power density of 225 mW cm−2 and a cycle stability of up to 320 h. This study provides an important paradigm for the precise regulation of the coordination environment and electronic structure of metal centers through multi-heteroatom synergistic strategies. Although the non-metallic atom doping strategy has shown remarkable results in regulating the coordination environment and electronic configuration of M-N4 sites, there are still important challenges in practical application: the current doping process often leads to the random distribution of heteroatoms in the first or second coordination shell, and this uncontrollable spatial arrangement seriously restricts the thorough comprehension of the structure–activity relationship. To break through this limitation, future research should focus on the following three directions: (1) developing precise synthesis methods and constructing model catalysts with clear coordination configurations to systematically analyze the specific mechanism of heteroatoms in different coordination shells; (2) investigating the synergistic regulation effect of multi-coordinated shells (the first and second shells) to establish a more complete theory of electronic configuration regulation; (3) broadening the scope of research from the monometallic site system to the bimetallic/multimetallic site system to achieve synergistic enhancement of catalytic activity and stability through the organic combination of multi-metal center synergy and multi-shell coordination regulation. These breakthroughs will provide an important theoretical basis and technical path for the design of a new generation of efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts. 3.4 Carbon carrier regulation 3.4.1 Defect engineering Defect engineering can accurately regulate the local coordination environment of M-N x active sites by constructing defect sites in carbon carriers [130]. Compared with the traditional sp2 hybrid carbon material, the defect carbon carrier can effectively break the charge symmetry arrangement of the metal site due to its higher charge and spin density [131]. This regulation can simultaneously optimize the electronic configuration of the active site, the d-band center position, and the intermediate adsorption behavior, thereby significantly enhancing the catalytic efficiency. Furthermore, the charge transfer effect between carbon defects and metal atoms further strengthens the metal-support interaction and contributes to the stabilization of the active center. Yi et al. [132] constructed the Fe-NC catalyst with controllable defect number and atomically dispersed Fe-N4 sites by fine-tuning the formation degree of carbon defects through CO2 activation. Theoretical calculations show that the change in the number of defects can fine-tune the adsorption energy of the oxygen intermediate by changing the d-orbital electron structure of the Fe center, thereby affecting the intrinsic ORR activity. Therefore, the Fe-NC catalyst with an appropriate number of defects exhibits excellent ORR activity in an acidic environment, and its half-wave potential is as high as 0.83 V. The PEMFC assembled based on the Fe-NC catalyst obtains a peak power density of up to 1.1 W cm−2. On this basis, Li et al. [133] succeeded in constructing the active centers with low coordination Fe-N3 and carbon vacancies in the Fe/N co-doped carbon system (Fe-N3/CV). DFT calculations reveal that the low-coordinated Fe-N3 sites coupled with carbon defects induce a downshift of the d-band center in Fe-N3/CV. This electronic modulation enhances the electron-donating capacity of the Fe site, which subsequently weakens the interaction between the Fe center and *OH intermediate. As a result, the energy barrier for *OH desorption is significantly reduced, ultimately accelerating the ORR kinetics. The Fe-N-C catalyst demonstrates remarkable intrinsic activity in both alkaline and acidic media, exhibiting E 1/2 of 0.92 and 0.77 V, respectively. This work provides an important reference for the design of efficient low-coordination M-N x /carbon defect synergistic catalytic systems. Carbon defects can not only synergize with the low coordination structure but also couple with the asymmetric first coordination shell to synergistically optimize the electronic configuration of the active center and enhance the catalytic efficiency. Ji et al. [134] constructed high-density Fe active centers on defective nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets through the interface microenvironment regulation strategy to successfully prepare the Fe1/DNC electrocatalyst (Fig. 12 a).
