Microscopic kinetic simulation confirms that FeN4(OH) is the real active center of the system under reaction conditions. The synergistic effect of this asymmetrically coordinated FeN4(OH) site and defect-induced electronic effect makes the catalyst display exceptional ORR efficiency under alkaline, acidic, and neutral conditions. The ZAB assembled based on this catalyst exhibits high peak power density and outstanding cycle durability. The theoretical calculation further shows that the carbon defects adjacent to the FeN4(OH) site can induce the electron rearrangement through an induced effect to modulate the hybridization degree between the Fe 3d and O 2p orbitals, thus synergistically optimizing the energy barriers of *OOH generation and *OH reduction and significantly enhancing the catalytic activity and stability under full pH conditions. In addition to the axial coordination in the first shell, the O atoms coordinated in the plane of the first shell and the adjacent defects can also synergistically induce changes in the d orbital energy level and spin polarization of the Fe center. Li et al. [135] successfully constructed the Fe-N/O-C catalyst with an asymmetric Fe-N3O coordination structure and adjacent defects, which demonstrated the d-orbital electron spin configuration of Fe centers can be efficiently modulated by the precise design of the coordination chemical environment. The catalyst exhibits enhanced ORR activity, with E 1/2 in alkaline and acidic electrolytes reaching 0.927 and 0.80 V, respectively. The assembled ZAB and PEMFC based on this catalyst achieve peak power densities of 490 and 1179 mW cm−2, respectively. Theoretical studies and in situ Raman spectroscopy reveal that the coordination O atom and the defect-induced effect synergistically promote the charge redistribution of the Fe center and the downward shift of the d-band center so that the d-orbital electrons of the Fe center transition from the low-spin state to the medium-spin state. This electronic state change improves the adsorption behavior of oxygen intermediates and transforms the rate-determining step from *OH desorption to *OOH formation. In addition, defects can also promote the dynamic structural reconstruction of oxygen coordination asymmetric active sites, thereby improving the catalytic efficiency. Koh et al. [136] employed a facile thermal treatment method to achieve an atomic-scale transition from the Co-N4 configuration to the Co-N3-oxo configuration, where defects and asymmetric oxygen coordination coexist (Fig. 12b). In situ spectroscopic observation reveals that defects can induce the rapid transformation of the Co-N3-oxo structure into the CoOOH phase with abundant μ2-O-Co3+ sites during the OER process (Fig. 12c). First-principles calculations confirm that this rapid phase transition can effectively stabilize the charge state of Co and optimize the adsorption equilibrium of OER intermediates, thereby achieving rapid OER kinetics. The synergistic effect of the second coordination shell doping and the adjacent defects of the metal site can further aggravate the local distortion of the electron distribution at the metal site, thereby significantly regulating the activity and stability of the bifunctional oxygen electrocatalytic reaction. Ji et al. [58] prepared atomically dispersed Fe1/NCP catalysts on porous defective nitrogen and phosphorus co-doped carbon substrates (Fig. 12d). In situ characterization combined with theoretical calculation confirms that the introduction of P atoms in the second coordination shell of Fe-N4 and the coexistence of defects around the asymmetric site of Fe-N4P1 synergistically lead to the rearrangement of the electron cloud density of the Fe site to obtain the optimal adsorption strength with oxygen intermediates. The catalyst exhibits ideal four-electron transfer path selectivity with excellent OER and ORR activity and stability. This study opens a promising design of efficient bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysts through the synergistic regulation of the second coordination shell and carbon defects. 3.4.2 Geometric structure design As a core strategy for the geometric structure design of carbon support, strain engineering optimizes the coordination geometry of active sites by inducing lattice distortion through precise regulation of the spatial arrangement of atoms [137,138]. This structural regulation triggers a significant charge transfer between the metal site and the carbon carrier, thereby adjusting the d-band center position, making the adsorption/desorption energy of the oxygen intermediate closer to the thermodynamic optimal value, and ultimately improving the electrocatalytic activity. Zhang et al. [59] developed a simple one-step pyrolysis strategy. Through the electrostatic interaction between Co porphyrin and positively charged helical polypyrrole, the atomically dispersed Co-N4 sites were firmly anchored on the surface of helical carbon nanotubes (HCNTs), and the Co-N-C@HCNT catalyst with curved structure was successfully prepared (Fig. 13 a). As shown in Fig. 13(b), the bending configuration leads to an enhanced charge transfer between N and C atoms around Co, and the outermost C atom exhibits obvious charge loss, indicating an increase in charge density in the active center region. Theoretical calculations confirm that this curved structure can increase the charge density of the Co site and move down the d-band center, thereby enhancing the electrocatalytic activity. Benefiting from these properties, Co-N-C@HCNT displays exceptional ORR performance and stability, and the ZAB assembled with it exhibits excellent cycle durability. This study provides an innovative strategy for the construction of efficient and stable helical M-N-C catalysts through strain engineering. The precise modulation of the surface curvature of the carbon support can induce a significant strain effect, effectively optimize the metal-support interaction, and adjust the electronic configuration of the metal active site, thereby reducing the reaction energy barrier and accelerating the catalytic kinetic process. Chen et al. [139] synthesized a novel FeN4-hcC catalyst with dense FeN4 sites on hierarchical porous carbon with a highly curved carbon surface. Theoretical calculations show that the curved carbon support fine-tunes the local coordination environment of the Fe center, reduces the energy of the Fe d-band center, and weakens the adsorption of *OH, thereby enhancing the intrinsic ORR activity and stability. Therefore, FeN4-hcC exhibits excellent ORR activity in an acidic environment, and the half-wave potential is as high as 0.85 V. In addition, the FeN4-hcC-based PEMFC exhibits a peak power density of 0.592 W cm−2 and a durability of more than 30,000 cycles. On this basis, Wang et al. [140] successfully anchored the Fe-N4 site on the highly curved nitrogen-doped carbon dodecahedron with a concave structure by using a mesoporous silica-protected pyrolysis method to prepare the Fe SA/NhcC catalyst (Fig. 13c, d). Theoretical calculation and in situ characterization confirm that the high curvature of the carbon substrate can shorten the FeN bond length, promote the redistribution of space charge at the Fe-N4 site, and lead to a downward shift of the d-band center. This synergistic regulation of geometric and electronic structures leads to stronger dynamic interactions of the curved Fe-N4 sites with oxygen intermediates, which optimize the adsorption energies of *OOH and *OH intermediates (Fig. 13e). The catalyst exhibits excellent ORR catalytic performance with the E 1/2 of 0.926 V. The ZAB assembled with it exhibits excellent discharge performance, long-term cycle stability, and high energy conversion efficiency. This research represents an important theoretical foundation for regulating the geometric/electronic properties of active centers through strain engineering of carbon carriers. In addition to strain engineering, the diversified regulation of the geometric structure of the carrier can be realized by accurately constructing the asymmetric edge anchoring sites of the carbon carrier, which provides a new dimension for the design of the coordination environment of the active site. Studies have confirmed that the anchoring effect of the edge sites of the carbon carrier on the metal atoms is significantly better than that of the in-plane sites, which can form a more active catalytic center [141]. However, due to the high atomic packing density of traditional graphene-like carbon carriers, the proportion of edge carbon atoms is limited. The use of hydrogen-substituted graphdiyne (HsGDY) as a carrier can break through this limitation and construct novel edge-active sites. Li et al. [142] successfully constructed asymmetric edge anchoring sites to stabilize Mn atoms and prepared Mn-N-HsGDY catalysts by introducing sp-N and py-N nitrogen configurations into the inherent defect region of HsGDY (Fig. 13f). The unique hexagonal macrocyclic structure of the carrier not only promotes the formation of edge sites but also provides a spatial advantage for the coordination of OH ligands with Mn atoms (Fig. 13g). XAS analysis shows that the Mn atom coordinates with two nitrogen configurations and OH ligands to form an asymmetric active center. Theoretical calculations confirm that the synergistic effect of the electron-withdrawing sp-N and the OH ligand moves the d-band center of Mn downward, which effectively promotes the *OH desorption process. The catalyst exhibits excellent ORR activity, and the flexible solid-state ZAB based on it maintains stable cycle performance under different bending conditions, showing the application prospect in the field of flexible electronics. This study promotes the construction of efficient asymmetric catalytic centers through carbon carrier edge engineering. Although some progress has been made in the current research on carbon carrier regulation, there are still several directions that need to be broken through. First of all, the existing defect engineering and geometric structure design mainly focus on monometallic site catalysts, and the research on the regulation of bimetallic and trimetallic site catalysts is still insufficient, which limits the further improvement of catalytic activity. Secondly, although the synergistic effect of defect engineering with a low coordination environment and single coordination shell has been reported, its synergistic mechanism with the multi-coordination shell remains to be thoroughly explored. Moreover, synergistic research on the strategies of carbon carrier geometry design and coordination number regulation, non-metallic heteroatom doping, and defect engineering is still relatively scarce. Future research should focus on the development of multi-strategy synergistic regulation and the exploration of novel carbon carriers (such as biomass carbon) with diverse geometric structures and abundant edge anchoring sites. 4 Conclusions and perspectives Non-noble metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts have attracted extensive attention due to their active sites with adjustable coordination environments and flexible electronic structures. However, the traditional planar symmetric structure of M-N4 severely limits its intrinsic oxygen electrocatalytic activity, which makes it difficult to facilitate the adsorption/desorption behavior of oxygen intermediates. Therefore, accurate modulation of the coordination environment of the M-N4 site to adjust its geometric configuration and electronic structure is the key to enhancing the catalytic efficiency and durability. In this paper, the reaction mechanisms of ORR and OER are discussed, and then the strategies for optimizing the M-N-C coordination environment in recent years are systematically reviewed, including metal site regulation (bi/tri-metal synergy); coordination number engineering (such as M-N3 and M-N5 asymmetric configurations); non-metallic atom doping (heteroatom modification such as B, S, and P); and carbon carrier regulation (defect/strain engineering and edge site design). The M-N-C catalyst based on the optimized coordination environment exhibits excellent electrochemical performance in metal-air batteries and fuel cells (Table 1 ). Although important progress has been made in the field of targeted regulation of the M-N4 coordination structure, many challenges remain for large-scale applications. Future research needs to focus on multiple synergistic strategies, precise synthesis technology, in situ characterization techniques, and theoretical simulation (Fig. 14 ). (1) Multiple synergistic strategies refer to the synergistic effect of combining multiple optimization strategies to achieve functional complementarity and exert their respective advantages. Typical synergistic strategies include the combination of multi-metal sites and coordination number engineering [54], the synergy of multi-metal sites and non-metal atom doping [102], the coupling of non-metal atom doping and defect engineering [58], and the combination of coordination number engineering and defect engineering [133]. Notably, the above strategies can be further used in combination to accurately optimize the coordination environment of the active center through multiple synergies. The multi-strategy synergy not only integrates the advantages of a single strategy but also regulates the electronic structure of the metal center to significantly enhance the oxygen electrocatalytic performance. However, relevant research is still in the initial stage, and the mechanism of multi-strategy synergy and its potential for large-scale application need to be thoroughly explored in the future. (2) The precise synthesis of M-N-C catalysts with a customized coordination environment still faces many challenges, which are mainly reflected in the following three aspects: Firstly, the difficulty of controllable synthesis of multi-metal sites. Although multi-metal site catalysts can optimize the electronic configuration and enhance the catalytic activity through synergistic effects, their synthesis is still in the exploratory stage. The spatial distribution (position and spacing) and coordination configuration of metal sites are difficult to regulate accurately, making it difficult to distinguish the active sites and restricting the in-depth study of the structure–activity relationship. Secondly, the random problem of non-metallic heteroatom doping. Heteroatom doping can optimize the adsorption behavior of oxygen intermediates by directly coordinating metal centers or modifying carbon carriers. However, the existing synthesis methods usually lead to the random distribution of heteroatoms, which makes it difficult to achieve accurate positioning of doping sites, hindering the clear understanding of the mechanism of heteroatom action and the further optimization of the coordination environment. Finally, the controllability of carbon carrier defects is insufficient. Although defect engineering (such as vacancies and edge defects) can stabilize metal sites and enhance their interaction with the support, there is still a lack of universal methods to precisely regulate the density and size of defects, which affects the uniformity and performance reproducibility of the catalyst. To break through the above bottlenecks, it is necessary to develop atomic-level precise synthesis techniques (such as atomic layer deposition), combined with in situ characterization and theoretical calculations, to achieve customized construction and optimization of active sites. (3) In situ characterization techniques play a crucial role in the dynamic study of active sites. Since the coordination structures of active centers in the M-N-C catalyst are highly complex (such as multi-metal site coexistence, variable coordination number, heteroatom doping, and carbon defects) and can be dynamically reconfigured during electrocatalytic processes, the combination of different in situ characterization techniques is crucial to reveal the real active center and their dynamic evolution mechanisms. Specifically, in situ synchrotron radiation techniques (such as XAFS and XANES) can track the evolution of the coordination environments of metal centers in real-time (such as the change of coordination number, bond length stretching, and local symmetry breaking), while in situ Raman spectroscopy and in situ attenuated total reflection-surface enhanced infrared spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) can synergistically monitor the dynamic interaction between metal active centers and reactants/intermediates. With the combination of the above techniques, the structure–activity relationship between micro-coordination structure and macro-catalytic activity can be established, which provides theoretical guidance for the accurate design of high-efficiency M-N-C catalysts. (4) Although DFT and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations can deeply reveal the dynamic reaction mechanism of active sites and establish its structure–activity relationship with electrocatalytic performance, due to the coupling of multi-dimensional parameters affecting the coordination environment of active sites (such as metal center type, coordination number, heteroatom position, defect properties, and carbon carrier geometry, etc.), traditional calculation methods still need to rely on numerous trial-and-error experiments to optimize the coordination environment. In recent years, the development of high-throughput computing (HTC), machine learning (ML), and artificial intelligence (AI) has significantly accelerated the discovery process of high-efficiency electrocatalysts, significantly reduced the time and economic costs of traditional trial-and-error methods, and opened up a novel paradigm for the precise construction of M-N-C catalysts. As an important part of AI, ML shows strong data processing and analysis capabilities. ML can quickly extract information about the composition, structure, and properties of catalysts from a large number of experimental data, HTC simulations, and literature through feature extraction and model training [143]. This enables automatic descriptor recognition and catalytic activity prediction to guide the design and optimization of new catalysts [144]. In addition, ML has also been successfully used to assist in the analysis of characterization data, regulate the catalytic reaction path, and optimize the catalytic reaction mechanism [145]. In summary, ML brings new opportunities and challenges for the design and optimization of M-N-C catalysts. By continuously improving the data quality, establishing a more comprehensive and universal catalyst data set, developing interpretable models, and realizing multi-scale modeling, ML is expected to further open a new way for the discovery of M-N-C catalysts with customized coordination structure and performance and push the field of oxygen electrocatalysis to a new height. Yi-Han Zhao received her B.S. degree from Northeastern University in 2023. She is carrying out her PhD research at Northeastern University under the supervision of Prof. Ting-Feng Yi. Currently, she focuses on the synthesis and characterization of electrocatalysts for rechargeable zinc-air batteries. Shan Zhao is currently a master's student at the School of Materials Science and Engineering of Northeastern University. Her main research interests are metal-air batteries and water electrolysis. Xin-Yu Liu is currently a master's student at the School of Materials Science and Engineering of Northeastern University. His main research interests are polymer solid electrolytes for rechargeable batteries. Peng-Fei Wang is currently an associate professor at Northeastern University (China). He received his Ph.D. degree from Nanjing University in 2021. His major research interests focus on solid-state batteries, Li-sulfur batteries, Li-metal batteries, and photothermal batteries. He has published more than 100 peer-reviewed SCI papers. His personal H-index is 28. Zong-Lin Liu is currently a lecturer at Northeastern University (China). She received her BSc and MSc from Northeast Forestry University and Ocean University of China, respectively. Then, she obtained her PhD degree in 2023 from the Harbin Institute of Technology. Her research focuses on catalysts for electrocatalytic reactions, mainly for hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, water splitting, and zinc-air batteries. Jie Shu is currently a full professor at Ningbo University. He received his Ph.D. degree from the Institute of Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He ever worked as a postdoctoral researcher at National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology (Japan), Université de Picardie Jules Verne, and Centre National de la Recherché Scientifique (France). He has focused for more than 25 years on a fundamental understanding of the chemistry and electrochemistry governing the performance of rechargeable batteries. He has published more than 400 papers, 2 book chapters, and 80 patents about rechargeable batteries. Ting-Feng Yi is currently a full professor at Northeastern University (China). He received his M.S. degree in applied chemistry in 2004 and Ph.D. degree in chemical engineering and technology from Harbin Institute of Technology in 2007. He has focused for more than 23 years on a fundamental understanding of the chemistry and electrochemistry governing the performance of rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors. He has published more than 230 papers, 4 book chapters, and 16 patents about energy materials.

coredata.dc:description: The development of highly efficient non-precious metal-nitrogen-carbon (M-N-C) electrocatalysts is a key scientific issue for improving the performance of metal-air batteries and fuel cells. Due to the symmetric charge distribution of the traditional M-N4 active site, the adsorption energy of the key oxygen intermediates in the process of oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is difficult to reach the optimal value, which seriously limits the catalytic efficiency. The core of solving this problem lies in the accurate modulation of the coordination environment of the M-N4 site, which can realize the breakthrough improvement of the catalytic performance by synergistically optimizing the geometric configuration and electronic structure. In this paper, we systematically analyze the ORR/OER reaction mechanism and then comprehensively review the four main strategies to optimize the coordination environment of M-N-C: metal site regulation, coordination number engineering, non-metal atom doping, and carbon support regulation. Through an in-depth analysis of the structure–activity relationship between the coordination configuration and catalytic performance, the core challenges faced by current research are pointed out, and future research directions are envisioned. This work aims to provide theoretical references for the directional construction of highly efficient M-N-C catalysts with optimized coordination environments.
